--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, samurai@x wrote:
> And there are those in the center, who adopt some conservative and 
some
> liberal views, who also do not like the thoughts of military style
> firearms on the streets. I am more than happy to oblige the hunter, 
the
> marksman, and the collector their rifles and hunting weapons of all
> sorts.

There's so much I could comment on, but I'm trying to limit my time 
on line per my better half's desire.  So let me just say that the 
Second Amendment isn't about duck or deer hunting, it's about killing 
people with firearms, particulary people within the government, 
should such government turn on the people it is supposed to 
represent.  As such, the protection for a handgun (a defensive, last 
ditch weapon in a major armed conflict) is somewhat weak, but a fully 
automatic long arm is just what the Founding Fathers had in mind, 
given modern technological advancements.  This doesn't mean that 
private citizens should be permitted WMDs, but a full "rock 'n' roll" 
rifle should be every citizen's right.  Unfortunately, besides 
killing renegade politicians, it is pretty lethal in the hands of 
psychopaths.  And in order to preclude this, liberals believe it is 
correct to forego the Second Amendment, and give up the right to 
resist an oppressive government, thinking that the kind, just and 
benevolent government elected by the people could never turn 
virulent.  This, of course, ignores world history and basic human 
nature.  Anywho, Australia is indeed the road map for the rest of the 
liberal left world.  The "safety line" you speak of is never far 
enough along for those who desire complete safety (and in the 
successful pursuit of this, finally lose the safety of the whole 
society).  In an armed society, government exercises control at the 
will of the people.  In an unarmed society, people exercise freedom 
at the will of the government.  Not oversimplified, just is.

NC
